[SYNTAX]: Garbled sentences (e.g., "Russiathe addition...") with missing/misplaced words.
[STRUCTURE]: Excessively long, convoluted sentences impairing readability.

[TRANSITION]: Abrupt shift from statistical introduction to strategic analysis (e.g., Chapter 2 opening).
[STRUCTURE]: Disconnected paragraphs (e.g., "Could Germany have won..." feels tangential).

[SYNTAX]: Occasionally complex, lengthy sentences (e.g., "It is just as easy...")
[LEXICON]: Minor awkward phrasing (e.g., "It is difficult to understand...")

[TRANSITION]: Slight abruptness between paragraphs (e.g., shift to criticizing Ludendorff’s memoirs)
[STRUCTURE]: Repetitive emphasis on Russia’s sacrifices without clearer paragraph linkage

[SYNTAX]: Overly complex sentence structures (e.g., multiple nested clauses).
[CLARITY]: Awkward numerical comparisons (e.g., "by more than 70 divisions approximating about 1,200,000 men").

[TRANSITION]: Abrupt shifts between ideas (e.g., Warsaw to Falkenhayn conversation).
[STRUCTURE]: Overly long paragraphs conflating multiple ideas.
[CLARITY]: Assumes reader familiarity with historical context.

[GRAMMAR]: Jumbled sentence structure (e.g., "Who the of offensive in Russia...")
[SYNTAX]: Overly complex sentence constructions (e.g., "Notwithstanding the lack of arms...")

[STRUCTURE]: Abrupt transitions between paragraphs (e.g., shift to Ludendorff’s memoirs without clear link)
[CLARITY]: Confusing, incomplete sentences (e.g., "For calm and go towards tremendous Allies...")

[SYNTAX]: Extremely convoluted sentence structure (e.g., "So Russia received as her towards fulfill of quantity did her...").
[LEXICON]: Occasional archaic or less common vocabulary (e.g., "inconsiderable").

[STRUCTURE]: Dense, detail-heavy narrative with minimal transitional phrases between historical events.
[CLARITY]: Poorly constructed sentence ("So Russia received...") disrupts logical flow and clarity.

[SYNTAX]: Overly complex, lengthy sentences may impede smooth readability despite grammatical correctness.

[CLARITY]: Minor ambiguity in abrupt statistical source reference ("Studying Consequences..."), but quickly resolved.

[SYNTAX]: Garbled sentence structure ("It small of the true...").
[LEXICON]: Awkward phrasing ("souls of pure Russian blood").

[TRANSITION]: Abrupt shift from WWI analysis to post-war geopolitical speculation.
[STRUCTURE]: Unresolved assumption about reader’s knowledge of Versailles implications.
